A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 2 
Primary Abstract 30 
With recent increases in the size of datasets currently available in the behavioral and health 31 
sciences, the need for efficient and effective variable selection techniques has increased. A 32 
plethora of techniques exist, yet only a few are used within the psychological sciences (e.g., 33 
stepwise regression, which is most common, the LASSO, and Elastic Net). The purpose of this 34 
tutorial is to increase awareness of the various variable selection methods available in the popular 35 
statistical software R, and guide researchers through how each method can be used to select 36 
variables in the context of classification using a recent survey-based assessment of misophonia. 37 
Specifically, readers will learn about how to implement and interpret results from the LASSO, 38 
Elastic Net, a penalized SVM classifier, an implementation of random forest, and the genetic 39 
algorithm. The associated code and data implemented in this tutorial are available on OSF to 40 
allow for a more interactive experience. This paper is written with the assumption that individuals 41 
have at least a basic understanding of R.  42

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 3 
A Tutorial on Supervised Machine Learning Variable Selection Methods for the Social and 65 
Health Sciences in R 66 
In the field of behavioral and health sciences, selecting the right variables for a model is a 67 
crucial step in working to understand how aspects of human behavior are related. For example, we 68 
might want to know how oneâ€™s personality or other traits affect their engagement with a particular 69 
type of treatment or how the symptoms of a particular disorder may present. In many cases, 70 
researchers not only want to understand how these aspects (i.e., variables) are related to each other 71 
and to overarching constructs but may also want to use the variables to classify individuals into 72 
groups (e.g., diagnosing clinical disorders, determining participant complian ce, etc.). The accuracy 73 
of these classifications or predictions is greatly influenced by which variables a researcher uses to 74 
create the classifications. For example, if a researcher is interested in diagnosing someone with 75 
depression, the accuracy of the diagnosis would suffer if relying solely on the presence of a 76 
depressed mood. However, if they use a variety of variables like depressed mood, loss of interest in 77 
activities, hours slept, and change in appetite or weight, their classification would be more accurate.  78 
Essentially, researchers must think critically about building their classification model. A good 79 
model not only allows researchers to understand the interrelationships among variables, but also 80 
creates an accurate model in terms of predicted classes. Variable selection techniques can help 81 
researchers to identify and select informative variables to build these models. The use of variable 82 
selection techniques can lead to more accurate predictions, reduce the computational cost of creating 83 
the model, and improve the parsimony of the model by eliminating redundant and irrelevant 84 
variables. For example, variable selection techniques have been used to build models pertaining to 85 
identifying exposure-outcome associations [1] as well as predicting mortality rates [2,3], psychological 86 
strain in teachers [4], and nomophobia [5]. 87

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 4 
Behavioral researchers often turn to stepwise regression to perform variable selection. An 88 
APA PsychINFO database search for the term â€œstepwise regression â€ returned 222 peer-reviewed 89 
articles published in the last 3 years using stepwise regression for variable selection. Stepwise 90 
regression, however, has many severe limitations and statistical experts do not recommend its use in 91 
any context. These limitations include the inability to distinguish signal (i.e., true predictor variables) 92 
from noise [6â€“9], underestimation of p-values, and failure to replicate [10,11]. As such, many alternative 93 
variable selection algorithms have been proposed in the literature, but behavioral researchers have 94 
been slow to adopt these new methods in place of more traditional methods [12,13]. One potential 95 
reason for this delay may be the disconnect between methodological and applied behavioral 96 
researchers, as much methodological research is often inaccessible for applied researchers at first 97 
(e.g., complex techniques, lack of published code, or no tutorials). An APA PsychINFO database 98 
search for the term â€œvariable selection â€ returned 253 papers published in quantitative methods 99 
journals in the last 20 years, indicating that methodological researchers are dedicated to developing 100 
better approaches to variable selection than stepwise regression. Of these publications, however, only 101 
one is a tutorial [14].  102 
Given the clear gap in the popularity of variable selection methodological research and lack 103 
of tutorials on how to apply them, the field would benefit greatly from additional tutorials on 104 
variable selection techniques with demonstrations of how to apply them to psychological datasets. 105 
The goal of this pap er is to provide a tutorial on five variable selection techniques freely available to 106 
researchers in R. We will introduce the Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO), 107 
Elastic Net, a version of the genetic algorithm (GA), and implementations of Support Vector 108 
Machines (SVMs) and Random Forest that have been adapted to perform variable selection. The 109 
manuscript is organized as follows. The first section illustrates the importance of variable selection 110 
in machine learning and explains why each of the five methods method were selected. Then, a 111

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 5 
motivating example is provided pertaining to diagnosis of misophonia. The dataset was collected 112 
from a psychology research pool and represents an excellent example of an average dataset available 113 
to many behavioral and health researchers [15]. Within this example, there are three major sections. 114 
The first discusses methods using a logistic regression model (i.e., LASSO, EN, and the GA), the 115 
second discusses SVM, and the third pertains to random forest. Each technique is introduced, the 116 
code necessary to implement each technique is provided, and each technique â€™s associated strengths 117 
and weaknesses are discussed.   118 
Variable Selection in Machine Learning 119 
Variable selection is a fundamental step in the process of building robust and efficient 120 
machine learning models, and its importance cannot be overstated [16,17]. It serves as a critical 121 
mechanism for optimizing model performance and ensuring its reliability across various tasks and 122 
datasets. Variable selection is advantageous with any model (e.g., regression, structural equation 123 
modeling, etc.) because, as mentioned previously, it leads to more accurate predictions, reduces the 124 
computational cost of the model, and improves the parsimony of the model by eliminating redundant 125 
and irrelevant variables. However, there are additional advantages of variable selection when paired 126 
with machine learning models. First, variable selection helps to manage dimensionality problems 127 
(i.e., when a dataset contains more predictors than it does observations). Over the years, technology 128 
such as the invention of online data collection platforms like Prolific or the creation of mobile health 129 
apps has allowed researchers to collect more complex data from increasingly larger samples. As 130 
datasets grow in both size and complexity, the number of variables may also increase, leading to 131 
computational inefficiencies and reduced model interpretability [18]. By carefully selecting relevant 132 
variables, we can effectively reduce the dimensionality of the data, thereby streamlining the 133 
computational process and facilitating easier interpretation of the model [19]. 134

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 6 
Moreover, the process of variable selection enables models to achieve higher accuracy and 135 
better generalization capabilities. For example, van Vuuren and colleagues [20] found that LASSO 136 
created a model that was able to classify students as at risk for suicide with a higher accuracy than 137 
simple inclusion rules (i.e., predicting based on history of suicide alone). Pratik and colleagues [21] 138 
utilized Elastic Net to select variables that were able to predict smoking addiction in young adults 139 
with higher accuracy than previous research. By focusing on the most informative variables, the 140 
model can discern meaningful patterns within the data, leading to more precise predictions and 141 
improved performance on either unseen or new data. This selective approach prevents the model 142 
from being overwhelmed by noise or irrelevant information, allowing it to focus on capturing the 143 
underlying relationships that drive the outcome of interest. For example, researchers found that 144 
applying Elastic Net regularization to classifiers based on clinical notes reduced the number of 145 
features selected by more than a thousandfold, making these classifiers more easily interpretable as 146 
well as maintaining performance [22].  147 
Furthermore, the inclusion of irrelevant variables in the modeling process can introduce bias 148 
and adversely affect the estimation of model parameters. Additional, extraneous variables may 149 
introduce noise or confounding factors, leading to skewed parameter estimates and potentially 150 
misleading conclusions [23]. By excluding such variables through proper selection techniques, we can 151 
ensure that the model â€™s estimates remain unbiased and reflective of the true underlying relationships 152 
in the data which increases the ecological validity of study results and models produced. 153 
Lastly, a well-selected set of variables not only enhances the model â€™s predictive performance 154 
but also contributes to its stability and reliability [24,25]. Models built on a carefully chosen subset of 155 
variables are less susceptible to overfitting, where the model simply memorizes the data rather than 156 
learning meaningful patterns. Avoiding overfitting leads to more robust models that generalize better 157

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 7 
and are less prone to erratic behavior or unexpected deviations which may lead to harmful 158 
classifications (e.g., classifying an individual as having a particular disorder when they do not ) [26,27]. 159 
Put simply, variable selection is indispensable in the realm of machine learning. It serves as a 160 
cornerstone for improving computational efficiency, enhancing model accuracy and generalization, 161 
reducing bias in parameter estimation, and fostering the stability and reliability of the resulting 162 
models. As such, behavioral and health researchers must employ rigorous techniques and 163 
considerations during the variable selection process to ensure the effectiveness and generalizability 164 
of their models and conclusions. 165 
The five techniques utilized in this paper were chosen for a variety of reasons. First and 166 
foremost, LASSO and Elastic Net are arguably the most popular modern variable selection 167 
techniques within the behavioral sciences. Social psychology researchers have used such techniques 168 
to create better environments that promote prosocial environments for children [28] and health 169 
researchers have used them to model the progression of Alzheimerâ€™s disease  [29]. Implementations of 170 
SVM and random forest were chosen because of their strength as classification algorithms and 171 
because they can handle more complex data types (e.g., mixed variable types or non-linearly 172 
separable). Lastly, the GA was chosen 1) to introduce the reader to the concept of metaheuristic 173 
approaches to variable selection, and 2) because it has been shown to outperform more common 174 
methods like LASSO and Elastic Net across a variety of different data conditions [30].  175 
A Motivating Example 176 
 This tutorial uses the assessment of misophonia as an example through which we illustrate 177 
each technique. Individuals with misophonia experience strong, negative, emotion al responses to 178 
specific sounds (i.e., triggers ) [31]. The original data sample consisted of undergraduate students (N 179 
= 343) at a large southwestern university. Participants were predominately white (76.7%), female 180 
(69.7 %) and students (96.5%) ranging from ages 18 to 36 (M = 18.96, SD = 1.7). The dataset 181

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 8 
contains 106 independent variables related to both direct characteristics of misophonia and related 182 
characteristics and one self-report binary diagnosis variable. Since misophonia is still not fully 183 
understood (i.e., diagnostic criteria have not been set, and researchers are still trying to determine 184 
the most important symptoms), this dataset functions well as an illustrative example for variable 185 
selection. It is possible that some symptoms are unimportant for, or not predictive of, a true 186 
misophonia diagnosis. One should note that this dataset does not contain any missing data, as it 187 
was handled a priori using listwise deletion. For more information on the larger previously 188 
published dataset from which this data was selected, and background on misophonia, see work by 189 
Norris and colleagues [15]. One common problem for implementing variable selection techniques is 190 
model overfitting (see Figure 1). Cross validation is one common way to circumvent overfitting. 191 
This paper implements holdout cross-validation which occurs when one splits the data into test 192 
and training sets before conducting any analyses. Typically in holdout cross-validation, 70% of 193 
the data is used for the training set and the remaining 30% is used for the test dataset. This 194 
practice was followed in this tutorial.  195 
Methods 196 
Logistic Regression Models  197 
Regularization Techniques 198 
 199 
Two of the techniques discussed in this paper, LASSO and Elastic Net, are regularization 200 
techniques. Regularization, within the context of classification problems, takes the following 201 
form:  202

a regularization parameter (i.e., a tuning parameter), and ğ‘ƒ is a penalty function that will vary 204 
across regularization technique. The goal of regularization is to find the optimal balance between 205

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 9 
bias (generalizability of the model) and variance (specific model fit [32]. Finding this balance is 206 
achieved via the magnitude of the lambda ( ğœ†) penalty. A larger lambda will lead to a sparser and 207 
more generalizable model. One popular technique utilized to determine the value of the lambda 208 
parameter is cross-validation. As mentioned above, cross-validation occurs when the data is split 209 
into multiple subsets, the model is developed (i.e. trained) on a subset, and evaluated (i.e., 210 
validated) on another. This process is iterative, allowing for the selection of the lambda penalty 211 
that minimizes prediction error across different subsets. 212 
 An optimal model, in the context of this paper, is one that produces the most accurate 213 
classifications. Accuracy can be calculated using the following equation:  214 
TP + TN 
Accuracy =  
TP + TN + FP + FN (2) 
 215 
where TP is the number of individuals who were correctly classified as having a diagnosis of 216 
misophonia, TN is the number of individuals who were correctly classified as not having a 217 
diagnosis of misophonia, FP is the number of individuals who were classified as having a 218 
diagnosis but did not truly have a diagnosis in the labeled data, and FN are the number of 219 
individuals who were incorrectly classified as not having a diagnosis when a diagnosis was 220 
present in the labeled data. It is worth noting that researchers may want to use a weighted 221 
accuracy in their own research depending on the relative importance of a false positive versus a 222 
false negative. For example, a clinician attempting to predict suicide attempts may prioritize a 223 
false positive (i.e., saying the individual is likely to attempt suicide when they do not actually 224 
attempt) over a false negative (i.e., saying the individual will not attempt when they actually will). 225 
Non-weighted accuracy was chosen here for ease of explanation.  226 
LASSO 227

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 10 
LASSO [33] is one of two penalized regression techniques that perform variable selection. 228 
LASSO can handle data with multicollinear ity, be applied to various types of data (e.g., 229 
continuous, categorical, mixed type), and is adaptable to sparse data (i.e., multiple predictors have 230 
zero or near-zero coefficients ) [34,35]. The LASSO equation is as follows:  231

 The following code utilizes the cv.glmnet () function from the glmnet package in R [36]. 239 
More information on the hyperparameters of the function can be found in Table 1. This function 240

family= â€œbinomial â€, nfolds = 10) 243 
 244 
Through this model, we can obtain the chosen  lambda value. To obtain a full list of all evaluated 245 
lambda values, use lambda.model$lambda . One can also plot the k-fold cross-validation procedure 246 
to obtain Î» using plot(lasso.model)  (Figure 2). Although one may use the one standard error (1se) 247 
rule to select lambda, selecting the model with prediction error one standard error above the 248 
minimum cross-validated error, this rule performs poorly in regression [37], so we use the value 249

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 11 
which minimized cross validation error (lambda min). To obtain our lambda min value, specify 250 
lasso.model$lambda. min. 251 
Using this specified lambda value produces the coefficients seen in Table 2. Out of the 252 
original 106 predictor variables, only 16 were selected via LASSO, thus a sparse model has been 253 
obtained. The coefficient estimates obtained through a LASSO approach are biased by the nature 254 
of the algorithm [38], and thus research recommends recalculating them using a standard regression 255 
before interpreting the coefficients of the model. A comparison of the biased coefficients obtained 256 
from the LASSO model and the corrected coefficients obtained in the standard logistic model can 257 
be seen in Table 3. Obtaining the predicted classification prior to calculating accuracy is crucial. 258 
Accuracy values (Formula 2) are then determined using the coefficient estimates from both 259 
LASSO model and the logistic model. The following code can be used to obtain the accuracy 260 
values from the logistic model.  261 
a.logistic <- mean(outcomeTest == pc.logistic) 262 
 263 
The value obtained using the coefficient estimates from the LASSO model is an accuracy score of 264 
.86. The value obtained using the coefficient estimates from the logistic model is .89.  265 
Despite strong performance of LASSO on this data, LASSO does have limitations [39]. 266 
First, it is unable to select more variables than there are observations. Second, LASSO will select 267 
a single variable in the presence of multicollinearity regardless of that variableâ€™s predictive 268 
capacity. To combat these first two limitations, Zou and Hastie [40] proposed a new regularization 269 
technique called Elastic Net. 270 
Elastic Net 271 
Elastic Net differs from LASSO through use of an additional penalty to the regression 272 
equation. Elastic Net implements both the â„“1 penalty, or the LASSO penalty, and the  â„“2 penalty, 273

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 12 
or the ridge penalty, to the regression equation. With the inclusion of both penalties, the 274 
optimization function for Elastic Net is as follows: 275

Through the inclusion of the â„“2 penalty, Elastic Net selects multiple variables that are highly 281 
correlated while removing all irrelevant variables [39]. Thus, if you have a dataset with highly 282 
correlated predictors (e.g., a set of dummy coded variables), Elastic Net would be more 283 
appropriate as a variable selection technique than LASSO.  284 
We can obtain our lambda. min value using the cv.glmnet() equation as well and then use 285 
that value to fit our model using the following code.  286 
en.model.min <- glmnet( x=predTrain y=outcomeTrain, 
alpha= 0.5, family= â€binomial â€, lambda = 
elasticNet $lamda.min ) 
 287 
The only difference between this code and the code for LASSO is that alpha = 0.5 rather 288 
than 1. Coefficient estimates from the Elastic Net model and unbiased coefficients from a standard 289 
logistic model can be seen in Table 4. An accuracy of 0.88 was obtained using the coefficient 290 
estimates from the Elastic Net model while an accuracy of 0.80 was obtained using the coefficient 291 
estimates from the logistic model.  292

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 13 
Elastic Net also has some limitations. Namely, it may struggle with datasets containing 293 
many more variables than observations, it is sensitive to outliers, and, given that it is designed for 294 
linear relationships, it may not capture complex non-linear relationships between predictors and 295 
the response variable effectively [41]. 296 
Genetic Algorithm (GA) 297 
Unlike LASSO and Elastic Net, which utilize internal regression models, the genetic 298 
algorithm (GA) is different. Instead of relying on a predefined internal model, the GA operates as a 299 
wrapper method. This means that the user must specify which model it should use (i.e., a user could 300 
wrap the GA around a logistic regression model or something more complex like random forest or 301 
SVM depending on the nature of their data).  302 
A metaheuristic, such as the GA, operates at a higher level, employing strategies to 303 
efficiently explore the solution space (i.e., all possible subsets of the variables) and locate optimal or 304 
near-optimal solutions to complex optimization problems like variable selection. Unlike specific 305 
algorithms tailored to certain types of problems, metaheuristics like the GA offer flexibility and 306 
adaptability, making them suitable for a wide range of applications. 307 
The GA, inspired by the principles of natural selection and evolution, mimics the process of 308 
biological evolution to iteratively refine potential solutions. Through mechanisms such as crossover, 309 
mutation, and selection, the GA explores and evolves a population of potential solutions over 310 
successive generations, gradually improving the overall quality of solutions. Figure 3 illustrates the 311 
general structure of the genetic algorithm, depicting its iterative process of generating, evaluating, 312 
and evolving solutions. Each iteration refines the population, guiding the search towards promising 313 
regions of the solution space. 314 
For a comprehensive understanding of the genetic algorithm and its application to variable 315 
selection, interested readers are encouraged to refer to the work by Bain and colleagues [30]. Their 316

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 14 
research provides detailed insights into the underlying principles, implementation strategies, and 317 
practical considerations associated with the GAâ€™s use in solving two-group classification 318 
optimization problems.  319 
For this paper, logistic regression is chosen as the model around which the GA will wrap. 320 
The optimization function used in this paper is the Hubert and Arabie [42] Adjusted Rand Index 321 
(ARI). ARI is a measure of agreeability between predicted classifications and true (or known) 322 
classifications and can be calculated in the following way: 323

The R code needed to implement both logistic regression and ARI can be found on lines 248 325 
through 260 in the companion code file on OSF. For a guide of hyperparameters and their default 326 
values (if a default is selected), see Table 5. To implement the GA, the following code can be run: 327 
 ga.solution <- ga(fitness = function(vars)  
    gaOpt( vars= vars, IV.train= data.frame(predTrain),  
        DV.train= outcomeTrain), 
        type = "binary" , nBits = ncol(predTrain),  
        names = colnames(predTrain), seed = 123456 , 
        run= 5 
) 
 328 
To view the selected subset of variables from the ga() function, one calls, 329 
ga.solution@solution[1,] . Note, the returned solution (given by ga.solution@solution ) contains 330 
many potential subsets of variables, but by referencing only the first row (using the indexing [1,]), 331 
the optimal subset of variables as determined by the GA can be accessed. Since the ga() function 332 
does not have a specified method for model building, but rather simply returns a list of variable 333

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 15 
selections, one must first build a model to obtain an accuracy value for the selected variables. 334 
Given that the internal model we specified was a logistic regression model, it makes sense to use a 335 
simple logistic model which can be built using the following code. The coefficients from this 336 
model can be seen in Table 6.  337 
allVarNames <- colnames(predTrain)  338 
selectedVarNames <- allVarNames[ga.solution@solution[ 1,]==1]  339 
selectedVars <- data.frame(predTest[,selectedVarNames],  340 
    outcomeTest)  341 
ga.model <- glm(outcomeTest~., family= â€™binomial â€™,  342 
    data= selectedVars) 343 
 344 
After building the model, an accuracy can be obtained using the following code: 345 
p <- predict(ga.model, newx = predTest) 346 
c <- ifelse(p >= .8, 1,0) 347 
accuracy <- mean(c == outcomeTest)  348 
 349 
An accuracy value of 1 is obtained, indicating overfitting, as with the past models built in this 350 
tutorial. Current literature indicates that the GA is prone to overfitting [43â€“45], suggesting the model 351 
would not fit quite as well if a new sample was collected, despite the accuracy of the model fit for 352 
the test sample used in this tutorial.  353 
Support Vector Machines 354 
Support Vector Machines (SVM) are a class of supervised learning models widely 355 
employed in classification and regression tasks [46,47]. SVMs operate by finding the optimal 356 
hyperplane that maximizes the margin between different classes of data points. By maximizing 357 
the margin between classes, SVM achieves good generalizability and is robust to outliers [48,49]. 358 
SVM can handle both linearly separable and non-linearly separable data by use of a kernel 359 
function which artificially projects the original data into a higher-dimensional space [47]. 360

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 16 
Elastic SCAD SVM 361 
SVM by itself is a classification algorithm. However, researchers have created 362 
implementations of SVM that simultaneously perform classification and variable selection [50â€“52]. 363 
This tutorial uses an approach like LASSO and Elastic Net in that it selects variables via the 364 
addition of a penalty [50]. The penalty utilized in this tutorial is the Elastic SCAD penalty which 365 
when included in an SVM, reads: 366

for an SVM where ğ’˜ is the weight vector, ğ’™ is the input feature vector, ğ’ƒ is the bias term vector, 371 
ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘”ğ‘› (.) is the sign function, which returns +1 if the argument is positive, -1 if negative, and 0 if 372 
zero. All hyperparameters are set to default values in this tutorial. In addition, data needs to be 373 
restructured for this function. For a clearer understanding of the additional hyperparameters in the 374 
svmfs()  function, see Table 7. The svmfs()  function can be applied in the following manner. 375 
Bounds <- t(data.frame( log2lambda1= c(-10, 10), log2lambda2= c(- 376 
10,10)))  377 
colnames(bounds) <-c(â€œlower â€, â€œupper â€)  378 
svm.model <- svmfs( x=predTrain, y = svmTrainOutcome, fs.method =  379 
â€œscad+L2 â€, bounds= bounds, grid.search = â€œinterval â€,  inner.val.method = 380 
â€œcvâ€, show = â€œnone â€, parms.coding = â€œnone â€, 381 
seed= 123456 ) 382 
 383 
The output of the model created using the svmfs()  function has its own nomenclature that 384 
requires explanation. First, rather than referring to the coefficients as coefficients, the model uses 385

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 17 
the w parameter (coming from the term beta weight). The b parameter illustrates the intercept of 386 
the SVM hyperplane and can be thought of like the b0 of a regression model. The xind parameter 387 
tells the user the index (or column location) of the variables selected in the dataset. The full 388 
output can be seen in Table 8. To examine the accuracy of this model, the same predict function 389 
can be used as was implemented previously, but the outputted predictions will require some 390 
restructuring, as they come in the form of a factor with underlying numeric values 1 and 2 and 391 
they need to have numeric values of 0 and 1. The Elastic SCAD SVM model obtained an 392 
accuracy of 0.83. The code required to calculate that accuracy value is below. 393 
esvm.predictions <- predict(svm.model, newdata = svmTestPreds) esvm.predictions.formatted <- 394 
as.numeric(esvm.predictions$pred.class)- 1 esvm.accuracy <- mean(esvm.predictions.formatted 395 
== outcomeTest) 396 
 397 
Limitations of SVM include the researcher â€™s selection of the kernel function, computation 398 
time, and dimension constraints. By default, the svmfs()  function utilizes a linear kernel function. 399 
Since the kernel is chosen a priori by the researcher, for optimal results, an optimal function must 400 
be used. SVM models are computationally more expensive than a simpler classification technique 401 
(e.g., logistic regression) and will take longer to compute. SVM models face the same degrees of 402 
freedom problem as LASSO and Elastic Net, where it is limited by the number of observations. 403 
As such, an ideal dataset for SVM would contain more observations than variables. 404 
Tree Based Models 405 
Random Forest 406 
Another powerful classifier is a decision (or classification) tree. An example can be seen in 407 
Figure 4. From this decision tree, it can be concluded that anyone whose score on variable S5_57  408 
is less than 3 and score on variable S5_60  is less than 3 does not qualify for a misophonia 409 
diagnosis. Decision trees are not only powerful classifiers, but they also produce an output that is 410 
easy to interpret. However, decision trees are prone to overfitting â€“ so much so that overfitting is 411

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 18 
almost guaranteed [54]. One of the most efficient ways to avoid overfitting is by using multiple 412 
trees (i.e., creating a random forest). Random forest creates many decision trees using a randomly 413 
selected subset of the data to create each individual tree. The results of all trees are then 414 
aggregated to predict the desired outcome. Some major benefits of a random forest classifier are 415 
that it can be used with an outcome variable that has any number of levels [55], meaning that unlike 416 
logistic regression which only works with binary variables, random forest could handle a variable 417 
with 3, 4, or even 10 different levels. However, these trees are only used for classification, 418 
meaning that they do not perform variable selection. Thus, researchers have had to adapt the 419 
classifier to perform variable selection. The utilization of random forest in the Boruta  package 420 
performs well in many different conditions [56], and therefore, is the implementation demonstrated 421 
in this tutorial. 422 
The Boruta package contains a series of functions pertaining to variable selection 423 
techniques using different measures of importance to select the variables. A measure of 424 
importance simply indicates the value of a given variable to the overall strength of the model. The 425 
variables that are more useful, meaning that they are stronger predictors of the outcome variable, 426 
are deemed more important, and thus are more likely to be selected than those of a lesser 427 
importance (i.e., less predictive power). To run the model, a simple regression formula statement 428 
is used:  outcome ~ predictors.  Because all predictors will be used, a shortcut can be implemented 429 
through use of a period ( .) in place of predictors as is seen in the code below. If not, all variables 430 
were to be included in the model, the user would need to type all the relevant predictors names in 431 
the formula statement concatenated with addition symbols ( +). Knowing this, the model can then 432 
be built using the following code: 433 
set.seed( 123456 ) 434 
boruta.model <- Boruta(as.factor(MQDX) ~. , data= trainDat)  435

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 19 
The Boruta()  function classifies variables as either important, unimportant, or of tentative 436 
importance. Regarding the misophonia dataset, 15 variables were deemed important, 74 variables 437 
were deemed unimportant, and the remaining 17 variables were placed in the tentative category. 438 
For a list of all variables that were classified in each category and a visualization of the 439 
boruta.model  output, see Table 9. Figure 5 illustrates variability of the importance score 440 
calculated for each variable during the Boruta process, as well as their ultimate classification. A 441 
model can be built using either a) all variables that were not deemed unimportant (non-rejected 442 
variables) or b) only the confirmed important variables. For the purpose of this tutorial, only 443 
variables which have been confirmed important are included in the model. This model is then 444 
built using the randomForest()  function since Boruta()  internally implements a random forest 445 
model. The model is built in the following way. 446 
set.seed( 123456 ) 447 
selectedModel <- randomForest(getConfirmedFormula(boruta.model),    448 
    data= trainDat) 449 
 450 
The predictive accuracy of the random forest model can be calculated using the predict()  451 
function, just as it has been for other models. An accuracy of .88 was obtained for this model. The 452 
algorithm may not perform well with highly unbalanced classifications or in situations where a 453 
given level contains a very small number of classifications.  454 
Comparing All Models 455 
For a comparison of the accuracy values obtained by all techniques implemented in this 456 
tutorial, see Table 10. From this, we can state that the GA produced the most accurate model. 457 
However, there was no difference in the LASSO non-biased, Boruta, and Elastic Net models in 458 
terms of accuracy. Depending on the purpose of your model, you may want to use a performance 459 
metric other than accuracy. Within the context of our motivating example, it may be worth 460 
examining the following:  461

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 20 
â€¢ Sensitivity: given the individual truly has misophonia, how likely is the classifier to realize 462 
that? 463 
â€¢ Specificity: given the individual truly does not have misophonia, how likely is the 464 
classifier to realize that? 465 
â€¢ Positive predictive value: given the classifier claims the individual to have misophonia, 466 
how likely is it that the individual really has misophonia? 467 
â€¢ Negative predictive value: given the classifier claims the individual does not have 468 
misophonia, how likely is it that the individual really does not have the disease? 469 
Given that our example pertains to diagnosis, it is possible that one may favor sensitivity over 470 
specificity in that we want to minimize the number of missed cases. However, it is also possible 471 
that we would want to minimize the number of false diagnoses to save individuals the cost of 472 
unnecessary intervention. A confusion matrix (discussed briefly in Appendix B) might be useful. 473 
Alternatively, one could use the Area Under the Curve (AUC) of the Receiver operating 474 
characteristic (ROC) curve. One should carefully consider these factors when deciding on the 475 
performance metric by which to evaluate a model.  476 
 We can also examine the different variables each method selected (Tables 2 â€“ 4, 6, and 8 â€“ 477 
9). The GA selected the most variables which likely accounts for its very strong accuracy. 478 
However, Elastic SCAD SVM selected many more variables than LASSO, but had a worse 479 
accuracy. Given this outcome, it may not be ideal to use all variables selected by Elastic SCAD 480 
SVM in this dataset. There was only one variable (S5_57) that was selected by all five methods. 481 
So, there is a clear method effect on the variables that are deemed to be important. Within the 482 
context of our example, we could interpret this to mean that the question, â€œ Sometimes in response 483

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 21 
to sounds I feel rage that is difficult to control â€ is an incredibly important predictor for 484 
misophonia and may capture a defining characteristic of the disorder. 485 
Discussion 486 
This tutorial provided an overview and a practical guide for implementation of LASSO 487 
[36], Elastic Net [36], a genetic algorithm [57,58], Elastic SCAD SVM [50], and random forest via 488 
Boruta [56] in R v. 4.2.1. Proper analysis of the output as well as comparisons on the predictive 489 
accuracy of each method are also discussed. More information on R, other useful machine 490 
learning software, and some of these functions were provided in the Appendices. Lastly, an OSF 491 
project  containing all code implemented in this tutorial, as well as the data used, is available. 492 
Variable selection allows researchers to find parsimonious models that are also good 493 
predictive or classifying models. Given Râ€™s increasing popularity among researchers due to the 494 
free and open access nature of the software, it is of value to the field to provide more guidance on 495 
the variable selection methods available in R. In addition, the extent to which some of these 496 
methods overfit data should not be ignored when implementing them on real-world data. If a 497 
researcher is concerned with creating a generalizable model, it is recommended to validate the 498 
results not only through some form of cross-validation, but also through collection of a new 499 
sample. Through this tutorial, we aim to push the field towards more transparent guidelines and 500 
standardization for the use of variable selection techniques and machine learning in psychological 501 
research. 502 
There are many additional R packages that will perform variable selection using random 503 
forest as well as SVMs, but only one of each was demonstrated in this tutorial. The demonstrated 504 
methods in the current tutorial were selected because they are commonly used in the 505 
psychological sciences, are powerful techniques for both classification (e.g., diagnosing 506 
individuals with misophonia) and variable selection, and because they are all freely available to 507

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 22 
researchers in R. In a similar vein, we have included only five machine learning methods here but 508 
many more exist, and additional tutorials should be provided to applied researchers about how 509 
best to implement them following research demonstrating each algorithm â€™s performance to 510 
indicate which algorithm is best for addressing certain research questions. For the interested 511 
reader, a comparison of the performance of each method demonstrated in this tutorial can be 512 
found in Bain and colleagues [30].  513 
This tutorial presented instructions for using five variable selection techniques in R which 514 
serves as a useful starting point for understanding how to perform variable selection. We 515 
encourage the user to refer to each methodâ€™s full documentation for additional examples and 516 
detail. We hope that this tutorial makes these methods more easily accessible to the everyday 517 
psychological researcher, opens doors to applications of variable selection in new areas, and leads 518 
to a decreased presence of less powerful methods (e.g., stepwise selection) in the literature.  519

Appendix B 783 
The output of a randomForest()  model takes the following form: 784 
## 785 
## Call: 786 
## randomForest(formula = getConfirmedFormula(boruta.model), data = trainDat) 787 
## Type of random forest: classification 788 
## Number of trees: 500 789 
## No. of variables tried at each split: 3 ## 790 
## OOB estimate of error rate: 0% 791 
## Confusion matrix: 792 
## 0 1 class.error 793 
## 0 124 0 0 794 
## 1 0 24 0 795 
 796 
The random forest output contains different information than any other technique 797 
discussed in this paper because it performs a type of cross-validation internally through looking at 798 
something called Out of Bag error (OOB; sometimes referred to as the out-of-bag estimate). The 799 
OOB is an approach to measuring the prediction error of a random forest model or of other 800 
decision tree models. OOB error is the mean prediction error of a given sample, using only the 801 
trees which did not have that sample in their bootstrapped sample. This sounds potentially 802 
confusing, but it simply means that the OOB error is the average prediction error of a given 803 
sample of data when that sample of data is treated as a test sample rather than a train sample (i.e., 804 
a tree is evaluated on that data since it has yet to see it). OOB error is also used for other machine 805 
learning models implementing something called bootstrap aggregation (bagging). Bagging is the 806

A TUTORIAL ON VARIABLE SELECTION METHODS 35 
official term for only considering a random sample of the data when random forest creates each 807 
tree. It is unique in that it is a random sample that allows for repetition, meaning that the records 808 
for a single participant could be represented more than once in the sample. For more on the theory 809 
behind bagging, see work by Ghojogh and Crowley [59]. 810 
In addition to the OOB error rate, the output provides a confusion matrix, something that is 811 
often used to discuss the performance of a classification method. A confusion matrix follows the 812 
form below: 813 
 True 0 True 1 
Predicted 0 Correct Rejection Miss 
Predicted 1 False Alarm Hit 
 814 
It is ideal to have a high number of both hits and correct rejections and a low number of 815 
both false alarms and misses. It is possible that one may wish to allow for more false alarms so as 816 
to decrease miss rates in some cases (e.g., a doctor would likely rather have a false positive 817 
screening for cancer than miss a cancer diagnosis). In other cases, one may want to minimize false 818 
alarms (e.g., in the court system, it is ideal to minimize the number of innocent people who are 819 
sent to jail). Thus, it is incredibly beneficial to understand each of these statistics when evaluating 820 
the performance of a classification model, as they both factor into calculating accuracy. 821 
The randomForest() output provides a classification error representing the proportion of a 822 
given class which has been misclassified (e.g., a true 0 that was classified as 1 or the reverse). For 823 
the model demonstrated, there is no classification error for either class since perfect accuracy 824 
occurred.  825
